title: Trump says he won’t accept bad China trade deal and slams Iran in UN speech
text:
Getty Images President Donald Trump addresses the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday in New York.

President Donald Trump used a speech at the United Nations to turn up pressure on China as Washington and Beijing seek a trade deal, and called on all countries to act to counter Iran’s regime.

CHINA TRADE

Speaking to the U.N. General Assembly, Trump said he wouldn’t accept a bad trade deal with China and listed U.S. complaints against Beijing including currency manipulation and intellectual property theft.

“Hopefully we can reach an agreement that will be beneficial for both countries,” Trump said. “But as I have said, I will not accept a bad deal.”

U.S. stocks SPX, +0.11% were higher Tuesday after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin told Fox Business Network late Monday that U.S.-China trade talks would resume in two weeks in Washington. He also said that deputy-level negotiations between the two countries had made some progress.

IRAN

Trump also sought to rally world opinion against Iran, saying no responsible government should “subsidize Iran’s blood lust.”

Trump said Iran’s leaders were fanatical about acquiring nuclear weapons and vowed that U.S. sanctions won’t be lifted until Iran’s “menacing behavior” continues.

IMPEACHMENT

The president also swatted away a question about impeachment, amid revelations he asked the president of Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son.

He called the prospect of impeachment “ridiculous” and a “witch hunt.” Meanwhile, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has been quietly sounding out top allies and lawmakers about whether the time has come to impeach Trump, the Washington Post reported late Monday.
